awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Exploring Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) as a Solution For Secure Internet Routing
awd_abstract_narration:
Much has been learned and written about the fragility of today's Internet routing architecture because of inherent limitations in traditional network routing protocols and the way they are used. Whether by accident or with malicious intent, network operators routinely  disrupt network traffic on a regional and global scale, causing both service disruptions and data privacy breaches.

This project works towards alleviating these problems in the global network infrastructure by exploring the feasibility of a trusted routing architecture based on the Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI). This research effort will identify and overcome barriers to the design, deployment and operation of networks with secure, trusted routing information. The results of this effort will include a working example, from which network operators can learn how to ultimately create a more reliable international communications infrastructure with fewer threats to data security.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The core traffic routing technologies at the heart of the world-wide IP Internet retain several long-standing, well-known weaknesses that leave the network vulnerable to service disruption by both malicious and unintentional actions. The issue of traffic hijacking is a problem with several proposed solutions that have not yet seen wide deployment. The goal of this project has been to identify the impediments to addressing the known problems with BGP route hijacking and move forward with solutions to these problems.

This work focuses on the issues of BGP route hijacking and the proposed solutions found in BGPsec and the Resource Public Key Infrastructure, known as RPKI. The RPKI is a necessary first step toward deploying BGPsec and ultimately solving these problems. We focused specifically on the challenges to deploying RPKI in the Research and Education networking community.

In this project we tested and implemented RPKI software solutions available as open-source and as commercial products. We developed a testing and training toolkit for operators using the GENI project. The issues identified through this effort can be summarized in three areas: legal, priority, and operational.

Legal challenges: The current security solutions ultimately rely on a foundation of trust. In particular, a trusted authority must be able to issue certificates and assert something about them. In most cases, that trust relationship includes legally binding agreements with clauses related to indemnification and legal domain. For many stakeholders, these types of agreements are difficult to negotiate. In the case of many US institutions, these legal issues are still more difficult to overcome than the problem they are trying to solve. This appears to be one of the reasons that RPKI has seen wider adoption outside of the US.

Priority: While the threats to Internet routing are well documented and not just hypothetical, it is not the biggest active threat to most network operators. There are other security threats such as data breaches and denial of service that are taking higher priority. At this time, for the R&E networking community, the problems addressed by deploying RPKI have not risen to justify the cost.

Operational: The research team became frustrated with the lack of community interest and vendor support for solving the real problem. The RPKI is a first step toward other, more important solutions. However, those solutions have not been forthcoming from vendors which greatly limits the value of the RPKI deployment.
